item.title: [HBASE-12742] ClusterStatusPublisher crashes with a IPv6 network interface.
item.description:
On my dev machine the first network interface is an IPv6 tunnel. Hbase works internally with ipv4 addresses. Addressing selects the first tunnel to use. This causes the ClusterStatusPublisher its DatagramChannel group join to crash.

Fix makes sense. Although it does mean we are excluding v6 addresses from consideration in a generic utility class, if we cannot support v6 addresses or binds then we shouldn't be considering them.

I will commit this to 0.98+ later this week unless objection or some discussion develops on this issue.

This test is for a feature that is rarely used and with a test that is awkward failing pretty regularly (though not of late because we added ignore to some of its tests now). Should we disable the test rather than ipv6 (though our ipv6yness seems to have issues always)?
Yeah disabling the test would make more sense IMO
Jurriaan Mous You ran into this issue when running the TestClusterStatusPublisher test? Or were you trying to use or reimplement the feature?

I was encountering the failure in TestHCM which test the HbaceConnectionManager. I needed to run this test to be able to find issues in the new AsyncRpcClient. I always run that above patch to be able to run that test.

It happens because in TestHCM the "hbase.status.published" is set so the master sends out multicast messages of its status on which the test reacts. The multicast messaging is handled by a Netty datagram implementation.

It fails because the server started with an IPv4 address and the first network interface it finds on my machine is an IPv6 tunnel. And then the Datagram freaks out because those two are not compatible.

I think disabling TestHCM is not an option since it is such a core functionality test.

The best option is to make that IP stack a bit smarter on what IP version the cluster runs so it only fetches matching interfaces. I will look into it if it is within my capabilities to find a right solution.

I now have a new patch that should resolve this issue in a better way.

What I found:

  • hbase.status.multicast.address.ip default is 226.1.1.3. An IPv4 address.
  • My first network interface and thus selected ip was IPv6.
  • ClusterStatusPublisher failed because IPv4 addresses don't connect with an IPv6 implementation

Fix:

  • Detect which ip family the "hbase.status.multicast.address.ip" is. (Was already done but not used to select local address)
  • Based on remote address select the right type of local address by using a condition on getIpAddress in Addressing.
  • Default is still the same, it will fetch the first valid address it gets for any other generic use of getIpAddress.
